data.text: Frame Material for Bikepacking: Titanium, Steel, or Carbon?
Ti,steel,or carbon thoughts on frame material for bikepacking,currently on a carbon fiber ride?
Ti if you can afford it.

data.author: Anthony

data.text: What's the difference? Just enjoy ride.
data.author: Mike Beard

data.text: The most important thing you have to remember...and some people will chime in with "Steel is real" and other stuff that isn't useful because there are just far too many caveats, is this: Not all steel is created equal. Not all carbon is created equal. Not all titanium is created equal. Not all aluminum is created equal. Cheap budget high volume steel frames are miles away from the quality from a builder that uses custom tubesets (schedule, diameter and butting) profiles. Even in manufactured frames, a Surly LHT or Kona Rove is miles from the ride qualility of the light spirited feel of a Fairlight Secan. A China made titanium with straight-gauge tubing or generic tube schedule across all sizes is going to be miles away in ride feel from even a Mason Bokah aluminum frame... Material is not the end-all to be-all definitive answer. There is an incredible amount of nuance involved, and there's companies that know what they're doing and make a good product, and those that are just wanting a market share. That isn't to say a Surly, Kona or Chinese made titanium are bad bikes at all... Personally, my recommendation would be aluminum. It's durable, light, doesn't corrode like steel and inexpensive. With modern alloying, butting, and hydroforming techniques, a quality aluminum frame is really hard to beat in terms of performance....unless its ultimate performance that you're after. Really it depends on your goals. Fast minimalist bikepacking, weight is a key factor along with comfort...carbon Longest term durability, in my opinion steel but also aluminum. Titanium is very good, has a lot of great qualities but stupid expensive to get a frame that's worth the material. I just believe for bikepacking where you're strapping a bunch of gear to the frame, subjecting it to conditions outside the normal usecase (unless its a dedicated touring bike), aluminum is just the easiest material to deal with, and modern aluminum frames don't fail that often and often as cheap as a repair to replace and the old frame recycled. If you look at Koga bikes ....there is a reason their flagship touring bike is aluminum, and a lot of R&D and thought went into the frame before the material was decided upon, it just so happened that aluminum was the most balanced material for the application, and it is considered one of the very best on/off road touring bikes on the market.
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: #steelisreal
data.author: Gyula Jung

data.text: that's why people have to put in the effort and do their own research. If we are talking low grade materials I would still go with steel. All the pros still apply just as for higher grade steel, the only real con will be the weight. A Fairlight Secan owner
data.author: Gyula Jung

data.text: But what I am implying, and it the honest truth....a good aluminum frame is just as good if not better than a low grade steel frame and there are plenty of high-end aluminum frames that outperform high-end steel frames. There is just far too many variables to consider and factor in. A perfect example is that you can a high-end steel production frame like the Ritchey Road Logic or Fairlight Strael and stack it against C'Dale CAAD10 (or the present 13 if you want disc brakes) or the Specialized Allez Sprint...back to back most would actually prefer the aluminum bikes. There are some great steel HT MTBs, but the moment you add long travel or suspension, still just goes out the window....there are some that do it, but there really isn't a production steel full suspension bike on the market that competes with the Ibis Ripley or Ripmo AF and there are just far too many examples of superior aluminum MTBs. It's just a better application, and done correclty, a better product. There are places where steel excels, but I argue that in the past years of vast improvement in manufacturing...the gap has been closed or passed altogether.
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text:
you could be right but the main problem is identifying the good ones. Many claim that they produce high quality frame when actually it might be only the material that is high quality, but the build quality and quantity controls are just not there. Just as the Bowman Cycles roasted by Hambini here: https://youtu.be/YTDQ9vtoxTo
Cluster CRAP Bike Company gets Totally REAMED: Bowman Bicycles
youtube.com
data.author: Gyula Jung

data.text: Hambini does make good points about production but too often aerospace standards to non-aerospace frames and parts. He does blatantly overlook many aspects of bikes in things that often may not have as big of an impact as he makes them out to be. But there are times he does get things right. My problem with him is that he's the epitome of the YT algorithm....clickbait content pretty much start to finish....too much fluff, and the furthest from concise from presenter. So typically his content is amusing for a few minutes but eventually you just want to fast forward to the "meat" of the topic and then move on.
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: I love my steel Jamis Renegade s2
data.author: Chris Massimino

data.text: Just depends on what you want from your bike, and what you can afford. For me personally, it’s Ti. Carbon bikes aren’t typically made to be load bearing and don’t have nots of mounts. Steel bikes, as much as I love them, are heavy and prone to rusting internally. But they weight is the main thing. I know it’s not going to be a featherweight with all the gear on it, but a few pounds off is good for me.
data.author: Danny Prather

data.text: my 2018 Libre has 5 mounts on it,sold my steel Sutra because of the weight/rust factor. I really like the ride and feel of this bike,which I feel is important as well.Next step will be outfitting with bags,looking forward to the adventures
data.author: Byron Bailey

data.text: they main thing I’ve heard about carbon, it when you load it with gear, it feels like a noodle. I’m not willing to test that, especially that I’m a heavy rider.

data.text: Just looking for all the advice I can get ty

data.text: Your comments about carbon are off. Most carbon bikes can take a load of up to 270 pounds officially. Unofficially its closer to 300. Also there are a number of carbon bikes available with lots of mounts like the Trek Checkpoint.

data.text: If buying new, I'd go either Ti or steel. Nothing against carbon as my road bike is. However for bikepacking I'd go with sturdy & reliable. Or just ride whatever you have; my primary rig is an old aluminum HT that I've absolutely beaten the snot out of & it still hangs in there.

data.text: yeah, alloy is apparently the most common metal and found near the earth serface.i guess because it's light. It's easy to mass produce frames out of aswell. I had an eddy mercx alloy frame, I loved it. Until I got back on my old steel framedbike. Narrower tyres at higher pressures than the aluminium bike, and the steel bike road so much better. I still regret selling the aluminium one, but hopefully the person who has it now is enjoying it

data.text: Just "for bikepacking" doesn't seem specific enough to pick a frame material. What does it matter? Depends on what you want, and how much money you have. Of the ones you listed, steel is going to be the cheapest. Are you really going to notice the very slight weight savings of the other materials on a loaded bike?
data.author: Leif Warner

data.text: $: steel $$: Carbon $$$$$$$$$$: Ti🤣 Speed increase for all three: negligible

data.text: If you want to clamp stuff to the tubes, then steel.

data.text: From zero if I had the cash i'd go Ti. That said your carbon bike may have an inconvenient lack of anchor points but if it's paid for stick with it. Just my 2 cents.
data.author: Mike Kimber

data.text: Anybody telling you the ride quality of Ti is necessarily any better than a good steel frame is making things up, or just has never been on a good steel frame. That said, I don't ever take frame bags off my bikes or wash them much, so Ti is worth it. I'm still not sure I'd pay retail for a new Ti frame; I think my Ti fargo was $1600 for the frame+fork. Lynskeys seem to be a good deal still.
data.author: Philip Alexander Carlton

data.text: And anyone who tells you that steel is any better than any other material is making stuff up as well.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: Yeah but it's cheaper and for the most part no worse.
data.author: Philip Alexander Carlton

data.text: While that may have been true 40 years ago, steel today isn’t “cheap”. It’s mostly boutique type frames. Aluminum is far less expensive and “no worse” than any other material with the added benefit of being lighter than steel and titanium.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: I'm not talking about going to a builder. All-City makes great frames, some of which are suitable for bike packing. You can get bikes for less than $2500 complete, which is a lot cheaper than Ti. Just as an example. Also, I worry about the dent resistance of aluminum frames that actually have good ride quality. If you're always throwing your bike down in the rocky desert, that's a thing.
data.author: Philip Alexander Carlton

data.text: If your off to places more remote Steel can be fixed/welded. Ti needs specialist welding Carbon - Gaffa tape ?

data.text: I have all 3, and aluminum. My steel ritchey is set up as my BP bike and it rides awesome. But friends who have their carbon bikes set up, they’re about 6lbs lighter. My ti - very reliable, rides great. So your answer, depends on what you want to accomplish.
data.author: Gilbert Vargas

data.text: I like ti or steel for frame material personally.
data.author: Andy Phillips

data.text: Titanium if you have the budget. Otherwise steel. Carbon and aluminum are too rigid for all day epics. Great for a bike park session or a race, but they just grind you down on multi-day riding.
data.author: Barkley Phan

data.text: Calling bull on this. I’ve been using a Cannondale Touring bike for weeks long tours since 2003 and it doesn’t “grind you down”. The bike provides a better ride for all day riding because it is stiffer. My old steel bike couldn’t be ridden out of saddle without wobbling all over the road. The Cannondale rides out of saddle like any unloaded bike…i.e. I can throw it from side-to-side and it will track straight.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: I suppose poor frame geometry can't be compensated for with materials. All things being equal, I promise you will feel fresher riding a well built steel bike day in and day out.
data.author: Barkley Phan

data.text: rigidity of frame is little to do with material. Any frame can be made stiff or compliant regardless of material.
data.author: Keat Brigham

data.text: not if your carbon or titanium frame is also well built.
data.author: Keat Brigham

data.text: My steel touring bike was a classic touring bike with long stays and relaxed geometry. My aluminum touring bike is a classic touring bike with long stays and a relaxed geometry. The difference is that my aluminum bike is also a classic aluminum bike with larger tubing which makes it stiffer. The ability to ride out of saddle doesn’t have anything to do with “geometry”, it has everything to do with a stiff frame vs a far less stiff frame. That said, the aluminum bike is a much more comfortable bike than my steel bike ever thought of being. I have over 10,000 miles of tours on the aluminum bike…including several 80+ mile days and I assure you. that I feel as fresh as one can feel at the end of an 80 mile day while carrying a touring load.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: that may be, but I have yet to experience compliant ride from carbon or aluminum. Quick and light, but not compliant.
data.author: Barkley Phan

data.text: then you haven’t ridden the right carbon bikes then. No need to dismiss a frame material out of hand based on limited experience.
data.author: Keat Brigham

data.text: I'm glad you're happy with your purchase. I'm even more glad I have the option to choose a different path, because my experience is the opposite of yours.
data.author: Barkley Phan

data.text: So I have a Salsa Cutthroat and it is really great for a vibration dampening and I absolutely love it tons of mounting points and I put racers tape inside the triangle and anywhere bags my rub but if I had to do it all over again I might pick the TI Salsa Fargo or a bear claw￼￼
data.author: Brian Nelson

data.text: Once you get over about a 50c tire running typical bikepacking pressues with loaded weight and common loaded bikepacking speeds, I am a bit dubious that anyone can tell the difference in vibration/comfort betweeen frame materials. It's never apples to apples anyway as even the Salsa Timberjack Al and Ti frames are made different/ differnt tube shapes/angles. Handlebar grip type/cushion, seat selection and wheels could be much more of a difference. ( I've had many bikes of all different frame materials.) Overall weight, yeah I get that - Up to a 3lb+ differrence between a Carbon and Steel frame.
data.author: Ron Bell

data.text: Had them all, steel or TI all day long. Even aluminum over carbon. Just to much to worry about with carbon-bags rubbing, torq specs, cracks,….modern carbon is great but I prefer steel for ride quality and durability. If I was attending events and racing I may go carbon but not for backpacking and touring.
data.author: Matt Sysko

data.text: Steel for me, but I'm 6'5" 300# and I hear too many stories of "normal sized" people cracking their carbon frames, usually warrantied, but still.
data.author: Andrew Moody

data.text: problem is that lots of them are just stories. No one shouts about all the Ti frames that crack at the welds, or the steel frames that rust from the inside….
data.author: Keat Brigham

data.text: I moved to the PNW from NH, so I don't worry quite as much about rust, although have seen plenty. my buddy broke his Santa Cruz high tower, steel can at least be welded or massaged back into alignment Ti frame breaks are news to me 😬 and I don't trust aluminum... Too soft and it fatigues over time.
data.author: Andrew Moody

data.text: google “titanium frame crack”. Every frame material has its advantages and drawbacks. Some might be better in particular applications than others, but there is no “wrong” material, there are however many bikes that are wrong for a particular use.
data.author: Keat Brigham

data.text: yeah, those look expensive. And I agree 💯. Although you can do a whole lot with a Fargo 😁
data.author: Andrew Moody

data.text: I have a Ti and an aluminium. There are differences but the main thing is to just get out and do it. Really the frame material is not all that important, though I wouldn’t personally choose carbon.
data.author: Rob Leacock

data.text: nicely said mate
data.author: Maximilian Vitus Wageneder

data.text: Manufacturers recommend for their normal customers to be throwing away their highly expensive carbon fiber frames every 6 or 7 years. If your an avid bikepacker actually riding mountain bike terrain as apposed to gravel roads, obviously those carbon frames wont even last as long as those 6 or 7 years, before becoming unreliable for bikepacking on actual rocky mountain biking routes. To me, that is a no brainer. No way would I buy a $4,000 mountain bike that wouldn't last a decade. You could buy a $500 steel bike whose frame that would last twice that long.
data.author: Scott England

data.text: My Dream Bikepacking Bike (a.k.a.Unaffordable) is the Mootaineer ...Titanium 29’er soft-tail with 31.75mm (1.25 in.) rear travel with boost wheels & 3” tires.
data.author: Tim Nelson

data.text: Quality carbon makes the most sense. You're not going to be hitting jumps on a loaded packing bike. Ti is excessive.
data.author: Justin Bogart

data.text: Steel because it’s cheap and strong, if your steel bike falls off a cliff you can make a few minor repairs and ride on, you can’t do that on carbon
data.author: Jolly Roger

data.text: no steel bike I’ve ever bought was cheap. Best ride for sure.
data.author: Shawn Smith

data.text: fair point 😂
data.author: Jolly Roger

data.text: Ti, but make sure it fits you, as it is a) Expensive, b) Addictive. I've got two Ti and want more. Pluses: Don't have to worry about paint, as a Scotch Brite pad makes all scratches good again, Strong as hell, comfy ride response, lightweight, looks cool.
data.author: Glen Carter

data.text: Steel or titanium..
data.author: Michael Armalavage

data.text: Steel has the highest fatigue strength out of all of those materials, and it costs the least. It's up to you if you want to spend a fortune to save three or four pounds, but it won't make a difference if you're not in perfect race shape. Carbon is great if you want to race, but it eventually fail. And when it does fail, it will explode into tiny pieces and you will need to have your jaw wired shut for a month. I do own a carbon bike, but I don't plan on riding it after 10-15 years or if it develops cracks. Being in the emergency room sucks! My steel bike, however, I will keep until I die.
data.author: Greg Molnar

data.text: Carbon frames doesn’t explode😆, I’ve crashed quite a few and they’ll usually just break clean or start to feel ”spongey”.
data.author: Olle Petersson Börner

data.text: You should stop crashing.

data.text: I'm pretty grateful for my carbon Bombtrack Hook when we all have to lift our bikes up over fences/gates and mine is the lightest... I also just generally love the bike and it absorbs vibration much better than my previous aluminium bike so I don't get numb hands.. I do understand the durability of steel/titanium and have friends who prefer it though.

data.text: Ti. The compliance is incredible. It’s a lot lighter than steel. It’s a lot stronger than carbon. The only drawback is the price, of course, but if you are asking the question you know that already. I sold two carbon bikes I loved to get my ti bike, and haven’t regretted it for a second.

data.text: Steel then Ti. Ti custom build would be insane. Carbon is great if your racing shorter distances. Ti with a carbon seatpost, stem and maybe handle bar. Plus with steel and Ti you can us the boss's on the fork. Or a Ti endurance type frame with a carbon fork, us bike packing bags if your mid distance. Point is you need about 3 different bike to do long distances haha.
